snippet.textDisplay: Honestly Adam, I've been a machinist for years and I respect you all the more for making this video, putting yourself out there like this is important to remind others that it can happen, they're not invincible, it reinforces the  caution we all need when operating any tool.
snippet.textOriginal: Honestly Adam, I've been a machinist for years and I respect you all the more for making this video, putting yourself out there like this is important to remind others that it can happen, they're not invincible, it reinforces the  caution we all need when operating any tool.

snippet.textDisplay: Five years ago I was working with a new 12 inch slide compound saw and in a split second of distraction I passed the saw thru my left hand index finger.No pain,I could see my finger entrails,see the bone,almost fainted and was rushed to a five hour operation where a wedge of my palm was transferred to "repair"my finger supposedly to save it.Yes the finger is "saved" but totally useless.This after being a highly qualified carpenter and joiner for 52 years!I know the internal shame I feel daily over this accident.
snippet.textOriginal: Five years ago I was working with a new 12 inch slide compound saw and in a split second of distraction I passed the saw thru my left hand index finger.No pain,I could see my finger entrails,see the bone,almost fainted and was rushed to a five hour operation where a wedge of my palm was transferred to "repair"my finger supposedly to save it.Yes the finger is "saved" but totally useless.This after being a highly qualified carpenter and joiner for 52 years!I know the internal shame I feel daily over this accident.

snippet.textDisplay: Adam as an apprentice almost 40 years ago they would almost beat safety into us, my pet hate is people making YouTube videos who leave the chuck key in the chuck while setting up if you forget and switch it on you have a metal projectile flying out that is quite capable of killing you. It is all too easy to do things with machines like this and risk some really serious injury or even death. These things are not toys as I am sure you know. I think you absolutely rock I love your content it's very sobering even the best of us can make mistakes, keep making things that amaze me!!
snippet.textOriginal: Adam as an apprentice almost 40 years ago they would almost beat safety into us, my pet hate is people making YouTube videos who leave the chuck key in the chuck while setting up if you forget and switch it on you have a metal projectile flying out that is quite capable of killing you. It is all too easy to do things with machines like this and risk some really serious injury or even death. These things are not toys as I am sure you know. I think you absolutely rock I love your content it's very sobering even the best of us can make mistakes, keep making things that amaze me!!

snippet.textDisplay: Adam, thank you for posting this.  I’ve been an avid SCUBA diver for the last two decades and I am very comfortable in the water and 30 to 130 feet below it.  Sometimes I have to force myself to do my check-throughs of mine and my buddies equipment on a dive, especially if its the third dive of the day or the fifth day of diving in a row; and sometimes I feel a little silly doing it when I watch other seasoned divers skip some of those same steps.  This video (and having a good dive buddy) are good reminders that what you are doing when you dive is not natural, and that you are in an environment that while beautiful and mesmerizing, is actively trying to kill you: taking your air, putting pressure on your body, sometimes physically moving you against your will.  You can never be reminded of safety measures enough.  And its good to know that even the experts need to remember to be mindful  and careful.
snippet.textOriginal: Adam, thank you for posting this.  I’ve been an avid SCUBA diver for the last two decades and I am very comfortable in the water and 30 to 130 feet below it.  Sometimes I have to force myself to do my check-throughs of mine and my buddies equipment on a dive, especially if its the third dive of the day or the fifth day of diving in a row; and sometimes I feel a little silly doing it when I watch other seasoned divers skip some of those same steps.  This video (and having a good dive buddy) are good reminders that what you are doing when you dive is not natural, and that you are in an environment that while beautiful and mesmerizing, is actively trying to kill you: taking your air, putting pressure on your body, sometimes physically moving you against your will.  You can never be reminded of safety measures enough.  And its good to know that even the experts need to remember to be mindful  and careful.

snippet.textDisplay: Adam thanks man, I’ve worked in a power plant for 15yrs, we’re surrounded by high pressure steam, huge rotating equipment, & voltages from 24vdc to 230,000 vac. Things that used to be scary are now just normal everyday items to many of us who work there. Complacency happens very easily when you work with something every single day, dangerous or not, it’s very easy to get lulled into letting your guard down, & that is when most of our accidents, especially hand injuries, happen. So thank you for sharing that no one is immune to “stupidity” (no disrespect meant man)
snippet.textOriginal: Adam thanks man, I’ve worked in a power plant for 15yrs, we’re surrounded by high pressure steam, huge rotating equipment, & voltages from 24vdc to 230,000 vac. Things that used to be scary are now just normal everyday items to many of us who work there. Complacency happens very easily when you work with something every single day, dangerous or not, it’s very easy to get lulled into letting your guard down, & that is when most of our accidents, especially hand injuries, happen. So thank you for sharing that no one is immune to “stupidity” (no disrespect meant man)

snippet.textDisplay:
Adam : You did everything I would have done. (well except for a loose snare near a spinning tool) Watch for signs of infection in the next week or so. (red lines on your fore arm, injury or hand hot to the tough, swelling or smelling or fever) The most important thing you did is learn from your mistake. Every accident is a learning opportunity and sharing it is even better.
Shop/Lab safety is near and dear to my heart. In fact. (I've been gone long enough to talk about it now) I was the original Boston Dynamics Safety officer. In 5 years I (proudly) laid out, wrote and implemented their first safety program. I left behind a safety culture that, thanks to my capable replacement, continues today. (Ask Seth about Safety Pete) Thanks again for sharing this story. You may have saved someone else from the same or worse.
snippet.textOriginal:
Adam :  You did everything I would have done. (well except for a loose snare near a spinning tool) Watch for signs of infection in the next week or so. Every accident is a learning opportunity and sharing it is even better.
Shop/Lab safety is near and dear to my heart. In fact. (I've been gone long enough to talk about it now) I was the original Boston Dynamics Safety officer. In 5 years I (proudly) laid out, wrote and implemented their first safety program. I left behind a safety culture that, thanks to my capable replacement, continues today.  (Ask Seth about Safety Pete)  Thanks again for sharing this story. You may have saved someone else from the same or worse.

snippet.textDisplay: hand injuries are scary I have also injured my index finger i was a removalsit at the time working with a new guy . I was guiding a fridge trough a door and he wasn't listening to my instructions and he ended up jamming / crushing my finger chipping the bone off my second knuckle and making a decent gash in my finger. I was in the north west part of Australia at the time. i drove myself in a small truck to the hospital then was flow down to Perth later for surgery followed by months of physiotherapy. A "small" injury to the hand is pretty major in retrospect i now have 80 to 90% use of that finger now and it dose not cause any discomfort thanks to some brilliant surgeon and plastic surgeons. down the track there maybe dome issues but all is good now. LOOK AFTER YOUR PHALANGES PEOPLE. Good to see you back at it Adam love your work and work arounds.

snippet.textDisplay:
Glad to hear you're not hurt too bad. Lathes are great tools but definitely something that can bite you in a hurry.

Moms are wonderful for helping with injuries. Several years ago I got my finger caught in an angle grinder with a 60 grit flap disk, and took a nice chunk out of the end of my finger. Injury happened at my moms house, so went right to her for help, she drove me to the urgent care to get 4 stitches. Was very grateful she was there.
snippet.textOriginal:
Glad to hear you're not hurt too bad. Lathes are great tools but definitely something that can bite you in a hurry.

Moms are wonderful for helping with injuries. Several years ago I got my finger caught in an angle grinder with a 60 grit flap disk, and took a nice chunk out of the end of my finger. Injury happened at my moms house, so went right to her for help, she drove me to the urgent care to get 4 stitches. Was very grateful she was there.

snippet.textDisplay: As Stumpy Nubs mentions in most of his safety videos. If you go to the ER and ask about injuries with tools, you'll realize that the vast majority of injuries happened to professionals who knew what they were doing, but their experience made them over confident and caused them to put themselves in risk that no beginner would. Things like removing safety features from their tools because they "get in the way", trying to control kickback, holding things too close to the action part, and so on. All power tools have the potential to kill you and have zero regard for your integrity. And if you think you'll be able to react fast enough, the human body can move involuntarily in strange and dangerous ways in those situations, such as making your hand move into a cutting blade.
snippet.textOriginal: As Stumpy Nubs mentions in most of his safety videos. If you go to the ER and ask about injuries with tools, you'll realize that the vast majority of injuries happened to professionals who knew what they were doing, but their experience made them over confident and caused them to put themselves in risk that no beginner would. Things like removing safety features from their tools because they "get in the way", trying to control kickback, holding things too close to the action part, and so on. All power tools have the potential to kill you and have zero regard for your integrity. And if you think you'll be able to react fast enough, the human body can move involuntarily in strange and dangerous ways in those situations, such as making your hand move into a cutting blade.

snippet.textDisplay: Hahaha aren't mums the best. The last work injury I had was about 15mins before closing on a Friday when my finger had an altercation with a rather powerful sander, also just doing something stupid letting my guard down a bit. Not wanting to make a big hassle out of it and have to report it/fill out paperwork and all the bullshit that goes with working at a large company I taped it up with some electrical tape, walked out to my car drove off without telling anyone and then stopped off at my mums place. Where else can you get patched up and then walk out with some delicious home made lemon cheesecake?
snippet.textOriginal: Hahaha aren't mums the best. snippet.textDisplay:
Lucky escape. I play with electronics as a hobby, and as a kid I had my fair share of shocks from mains electricity. I'm surprised I'm still alive to be honest.

These days I only really play with digital electronics, so it's all very low voltage, but I have a super healthy respect for mains voltage and don't dare mess with it.
snippet.textOriginal:
Lucky escape. I play with electronics as a hobby, and as a kid I had my fair share of shocks from mains electricity. I'm surprised I'm still alive to be honest.

These days I only really play with digital electronics, so it's all very low voltage, but I have a super healthy respect for mains voltage and don't dare mess with it.

snippet.textDisplay: We were making a hotbed for our gardden yesterday. I was trying to cut a medium sized plastic hose with my pocket knife (i sharpen and hone it all the time, so it was razor sharp), it slipped and stabbed myself about an inch and a half deep into the outer lower side of my thigh. So yeah, accidents happen. Had to get stitches. Fun times. I think i got my muscle too, i am limping a bit. Not even mad, it is just funny to me how i made that stupid mistake. hehe

snippet.textDisplay: It's so easy to get lost in the moment and over look the dangers - especially, a tool so respected and loved. It is important too stay safe  - of course - for yourself foremost, but also for all of us - we all have a vested interest in your wellbeing as members of your extended family -  we understand your hurt and pain and we're along side you with this - and it's okay to call mom - hell no shame in that - we all would  and have done so in the past.😆 Be well and stay safe my friend..... and we'll keep on enjoying the person you are -  along with your fantastic content.   👍🏼 😎

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you so much for this Adam. I just cut my left index finger pretty deeply on my CNC Router the other day and had the exact same "Do not go to the hospital" mindset. I've been quite terrified and have had to force myself to be brave to utilize the CNC router again, but with your video it's really helping me get over the tremors. Thank you again, and hope your finger heals soon!
snippet.textOriginal: Thank you so much for this Adam. I just cut my left index finger pretty deeply on my CNC Router the other day and had the exact same "Do not go to the hospital" mindset. I've been quite terrified and have had to force myself to be brave to utilize the CNC router again, but with your video it's really helping me get over the tremors. Thank you again, and hope your finger heals soon!

snippet.textDisplay: Machines are fantastic to have. But they can be unforgiving. I worked in a steel mill that also did cold drawn steel bars. There was a auto welder that had these hydraulic jaws to grab the bars and weld one spool to the next. Those jaws could bite a 2x4 in half. I have seen many gloves with fingers still in them from guys not paying attention to the jaws. Instantly bites them off. Terrible injury. I am glad I got out with all ten.
snippet.textOriginal: Machines are fantastic to have. But they can be unforgiving. I worked in a steel mill that also did cold drawn steel bars. There was a auto welder that had these hydraulic jaws to grab the bars and weld one spool to the next. Those jaws could bite a 2x4 in half. I have seen many gloves with fingers still in them from guys not paying attention to the jaws. Instantly bites them off. Terrible injury. I am glad I got out with all ten.

snippet.textDisplay:
A few years ago I hear some noise outside, some kind of commotion so I race next door and find my neighbor clutching his hand wrapped in a rag. I knew something was wrong - he asked me to remove his work belt - the sort in which you can hang tools and so forth - he had been using a cordless hand-drill - drilling out holes in some large pieces of timber framing and he had somehow gotten builders mastic (a gooey sealing compound) on the wood drill bit. So he stops and puts the drill into his belt and picks up a rag to wipe the mastic off the drill bit and somehow manages to turn the drill on while it is hanging from his tool belt. The rag immediately wraps around the drill bit and catches one of his fingers and continues to spin. It's Not Good.

I turn up and then he then unwraps the rag in front of me to show me his injury. It's Not Good.

You know the magic trick where you show kids your hand and pretend your fingers have separated - look kids "my thumb has come off" - but it's just a trick - well this was no trick. One of his fingers was twisted off at the second joint and was hanging on only by the tiniest piece of skin. It's Not Good.

I immediately went into shock.... and at the same time offered to drive him to hospital. It's Not Good.

I was driving so slowly and I can remember cars were passing us and eventually I got him to hospital where he got fixed up after a very long wait. They sewed it up so good now you can hardly see the scar. {FREE healthcare in Australia}.
snippet.textOriginal:
A few years ago I hear some noise outside, some kind of commotion so I race next door and find my neighbor clutching his hand wrapped in a rag. I knew something was wrong - he asked  me to remove his work belt - the sort in which you can hang tools and so forth - he had been using a cordless hand-drill - drilling out holes in some large pieces of timber framing and he had somehow gotten builders mastic (a gooey sealing compound) on the wood drill bit. So he stops and puts the drill into his belt and picks up a rag to wipe the mastic off the drill bit and somehow manages to turn the drill on while it is hanging from his tool belt. The rag immediately wraps around the drill bit and catches one of his fingers and continues to spin. It's Not Good. 

I turn up and then he then unwraps the rag in front of me to show me his injury. It's Not Good.

You know the magic trick where you show kids your hand and pretend your fingers have separated - look kids "my thumb has come off" - but it's just a trick - well this was no trick. One of his fingers was twisted off at the second joint and was hanging on only by the tiniest piece of skin. It's Not Good.

I immediately went into shock.... and at the same time offered to drive him to hospital. It's Not Good.

I was driving so slowly and I can remember cars were passing us and eventually I got him to hospital where he got fixed up after a very long wait. They sewed it up so good now you can hardly see the scar. {FREE healthcare in Australia}.

snippet.textDisplay: It happens to us all Adam. You can do the same thing a thousand times the exact same way and then just one small mistake hurts. Get well soon and stay well.

snippet.textDisplay: I can tell you from experience that talking about your failures and mistakes is as you said very hard. But, you learned a lesson from it and you’re able to pass that knowledge on to all of your viewers. But from a medical perspective, you handled it fairly well and made a very hard call that may have saved your life, and definitely your finger. Kudos to you and I look forward to seeing more great content in the future. And from my limited dealings with friends who are pilots, that axiom holds true.
snippet.textOriginal: I can tell you from experience that talking about your failures and mistakes is as you said very hard. But from a medical perspective, you handled it fairly well and made a very hard call that may have saved your life, and definitely your finger. Kudos to you and I look forward to seeing more great content in the future. And from my limited dealings with friends who are pilots, that axiom holds true.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm an electrician and it's really easy to get used to be safe until you get zap and realize that feeling of dying from a simple short circuit. Same with machines, treat them with respect if not, it will kill ya.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm an electrician and it's really easy to get used to be safe until you get zap and realize that feeling of dying from a simple short circuit. Same with machines, treat them with respect if not, it will kill ya.

snippet.textDisplay: Accidents happen. I seen a guy smack himself in the face with a faulty lock wire tool. The wire went into his eye and was stuck. I’ve seen another guy get his thumb stuck in a grinding wheel. It ripped his thumb off at the knuckle. Those stories are better then mine where I was drunk and slipped in my bathroom. My hand smacked a glass swan that my mom collects. I cut the wrist open to the tendons. Took 12 stitches.
snippet.textOriginal: Accidents happen. I seen a guy smack himself in the face with a faulty lock wire tool. The wire went into his eye and was stuck. I’ve seen another guy get his thumb stuck in a grinding wheel. It ripped his thumb off at the knuckle. Those stories are better then mine where I was drunk and slipped in my bathroom. My hand smacked a glass swan that my mom collects. I cut the wrist open to the tendons. Took 12 stitches.

snippet.textDisplay: I sliced my tendon in my pointer finger and nerves cut in my thumb with a drill press with an Ill clamped scrap on metal, I feel your pain. It was 2 seconds that cost  me a surgery and months of use from one of my hands, nothing like having to use your elbow to hold something down while you sand with the good hand during the Christmas rush to remind you what a dumb thing you did, thank good I healed almost 100% and didn't lose my ability to sculpt.
snippet.textOriginal: I sliced my tendon in my pointer finger and nerves cut in my thumb with a drill press with an Ill clamped scrap on metal, I feel your pain. It was 2 seconds that cost  me a surgery and months of use from one of my hands, nothing like having to use your elbow to hold something down while you sand with the good hand during the Christmas rush to remind you what a dumb thing you did, thank good I healed almost 100% and didn't lose my ability to sculpt.

snippet.textDisplay: Honestly, it could've been worse and you did everything you could do. If for some reason, the butterfly bandages don't want to hold, add a few tiny drops of super glue before squeezing the cut closed and bandaging. I have a 24 year old son with adult ADHD who is also a maker.... we learn whatever we can to stay out of the ER. Plus, his body doesn't like stitches.
snippet.textOriginal: Honestly, it could've been worse and you did everything you could do. snippet.textDisplay: Just got my thumb caught & cut in the kickstand of my husband’s bike.  The wind blew his on top of mine, and in the untangling process, the kickstand snapped on my thumb, cutting into the thumb & thumbnail.  I immediately thought of your accident.  We managed to bind my little injury up tightly, it’ll be fine.  But I had the same feelings.  Really don’t want to have to waste any doctor or nurse’s time on stupid accidents right now - or expose yourself to what might be in the doctor’s office or ER.  So please be more careful!
snippet.textOriginal: Just got my thumb caught & cut in the kickstand of my husband’s bike.  The wind blew his on top of mine, and in the untangling process, the kickstand snapped on my thumb, cutting into the thumb & thumbnail.  I immediately thought of your accident. Really don’t want to have to waste any doctor or nurse’s time on stupid accidents right now - or expose yourself to what might be in the doctor’s office or ER.  So please be more careful!

snippet.textDisplay: I hurt for you Adam.   As a guitar player..... I saw that finger bandage and got a cold sweat.  Good news is that your injury is embedded in your head.  The brain is great for warning you next time.   That memory is filed in the warning drawer.    Heal well and soon.
snippet.textOriginal: I hurt for you Adam.   As a guitar player..... I saw that finger bandage and got a cold sweat.  Good news is that your injury is embedded in your head.  The brain is great for warning you next time.   That memory is filed in the warning drawer.    Heal well and soon.

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you for this video Adam.
I suffered an injury to fingers on each hand not too long ago from broken glass, and I've been having flashbacks of the incident every time I close my eyes ever since, on top of shame and embarrassment, and feeling just awful for having to make use of the hospital during these times. But seeing that you reacted in a similar way makes me feel better.
I'm an artist and a scenic painter. My hands are everything. And it was just a split second of thoughtlessness after hours of careful concentration. I'm days away from being healed enough to paint again. I can't wait!
Thanks again. Be careful out there, and be well.
snippet.textOriginal:
Thank you for this video Adam.  
I suffered an injury to fingers on each hand not too long ago from broken glass, and I've been having flashbacks of the incident every time I close my eyes ever since, on top of shame and embarrassment, and feeling just awful for having to make use of the hospital during these times.  But seeing that you reacted in a similar way makes me feel better.
I'm an artist and a scenic painter. My hands are everything.  And it was just a split second of thoughtlessness after hours of careful concentration.  I'm days away from being healed enough to paint again.  I can't wait!
Thanks again.  Be careful out there, and be well.

snippet.textDisplay:
I had a friend who plays guitar. He worked in the deli section of a grocery store.
While cleaning the deli slicer he lopped off a chunk of his pointer finger.
All I remember during that time was how how this guy lost a chunk of his finger, lost his fingerprint, and kept playing guitar. He didn't lost sight of what he wanted to do. He found a way and kept on creating and learned, and has stayed all the safer.

I now respect chisels alot.

snippet.textDisplay:
That hand, and that finger in particular, have been taking a beating lately. Nail has been black for awhile now. So much that I didn’t even really expect this story, thought it was about the previous injury that had somehow compounded.

Can’t imaging a world w/o Adam building in his shop. Seems so implausible. Guess I was taking Mr Savage for granted as well. I’ll try not to do that in the future, like so many other things these days... Day #26 of social distancing at home here in SoCal. Its been a year or so since 3/13/20. There was a birthday in there somewhere...

snippet.textDisplay: I totally get that feeling of shame. Familiarity and confidence tends to override caution when it shouldn't. I remember one time in middle school I brainfarted while using the bandsaw, went, "I should move those small cut-off pieces so they don't get in my way" and attempted to brush them away. Cut partway through my ring finger, halfway through the nail. Luckily, most of the damage was to my ego. You would never be able to tell it happened if you look now, but that taught me a LOT of respect for machines.
snippet.textOriginal: I totally get that feeling of shame. Familiarity and confidence tends to override caution when it shouldn't. You would never be able to tell it happened if you look now, but that taught me a LOT of respect for machines.

snippet.textDisplay: This is so incredibly relatable. I did the same damn thing today except it was a sharp knife in the kitchen. Didn't want to go to urgent care or the hospital. Called my mum. Had my husband super glue it back together. I'm incredibly lucky that my husband is a butcher and our knives are so sharp, it was a very clean cut.
snippet.textOriginal: This is so incredibly relatable. I did the same damn thing today except it was a sharp knife in the kitchen. Didn't want to go to urgent care or the hospital. Called my mum. Had my husband super glue it back together. I'm incredibly lucky that my husband is a butcher and our knives are so sharp, it was a very clean cut.

snippet.textDisplay: Oh Mr Savage you silly sausage. Glad you got away relatively unharmed considering the possible outcomes!!! Try and stay safe :)
snippet.textOriginal: Oh Mr Savage you silly sausage. Glad you got away relatively unharmed considering the possible outcomes!!! Try and stay safe :)

snippet.textDisplay:
I've heard that it's time to sell your motorcycle the moment you stop fearing a vehicular accident.

Well, anyway, glad you were able to deal with it. Looking forward to a long, fully-functional future of your awesome builds and words.

Nice Cap shield, BTW.

snippet.textDisplay: This reminds me of a lathe safety video I watched years ago, presented by a man missing three fingers on one hand. Every time he said something, there was that little part of my brain saying "so you did that one, huh?"
snippet.textOriginal: This reminds me of a lathe safety video I watched years ago, presented by a man missing three fingers on one hand. Every time he said something, there was that little part of my brain saying "so you did that one, huh?"

snippet.textDisplay: Anyone else have a wood part split out and have a thin wafer of wood fly last your head, close enough to brush your hair and then fly 15 feet and a wall near the 10 foot the ceiling
snippet.textOriginal: Anyone else have a wood part split out and have a thin wafer of wood fly last your head, close enough to brush your hair and then fly 15 feet and a wall near the 10 foot the ceiling

snippet.textDisplay:
Adam: First off, thank you for sharing this. Hopefully talking about it wasn't too uncomfortable, but you are an inspiration to millions. Someone else will learn from your example and you've probably just saved a handful of people from this exact mistake and many more from similar ones.
So again, thank you.

Second, please take the lesson to heart. I am sad to see you have to make this video at all, but you have many other tools in your shop that you can be a little too comfortable around at times.
I sincerely hope that you never have to make another one of these postmortem videos, but your slightly fatalistic "accidents happen" outlook is dangerous.
Yes, accidents happen, but they are almost always avoidable. The ones that aren't avoidable are usually named events (fire, lightning, flood, building collapse, equipment failure) or are acts of god.

Third, you are DAMNED lucky that the rag grabbed your middle finger and not your ring finger. This could have been MUCH worse. At the very least get a breakaway or rubber ring for in the shop.


Lastly, I know that I have been critical of your shop safety habits in the past, and I can be somewhat abrasive about it, but please understand that I mean it with good intentions. I want to see what amazing things you come up with in the future, and that requires you to be hale, hearty, and whole.

Please, remember that you ARE an example to millions of makers and generations of future makers, both now and into the future. Stay safe.
snippet.textOriginal:
Adam: First off, thank you for sharing this.  Hopefully talking about it wasn't too uncomfortable, but you are an inspiration to millions.  Someone else will learn from your example and you've probably just saved a handful of people from this exact mistake and many more from similar ones. 
So again, thank you.    

Second, please take the lesson to heart.  I am sad to see you have to make this video at all, but you have many other tools in your shop that you can be a little too comfortable around at times. 
I sincerely hope that you never have to make another one of these postmortem videos, but your slightly fatalistic "accidents happen" outlook is dangerous.  
Yes, accidents happen, but they are almost always avoidable. The ones that aren't avoidable are usually named events (fire, lightning, flood, building collapse, equipment failure) or are acts of god.  

Third, you are DAMNED lucky that the rag grabbed your middle finger and not your ring finger. This could have been MUCH worse.  At the very least get a breakaway or rubber ring for in the shop. 


Lastly, I know that I have been critical of your shop safety habits in the past, and I can be somewhat abrasive about it, but please understand that I mean it with good intentions.  I want to see what amazing things you come up with in the future, and that requires you to be hale, hearty, and whole. 

Please, remember that you ARE an example to millions of makers and generations of future makers, both now and into the future. Stay safe.

snippet.textDisplay:
I've been terrified of riding my bike for a while because my fears of getting injured.





I got better with my bike and more confident and within the first few weeks of having my new bike I forgot my breaks were a thing and crashed my bike, resulting in my now broken wrist. My first broken bone actually.
snippet.textOriginal:
I've been terrified of riding my bike for a while because my fears of getting injured.





I got better with my bike and more confident and within the first few weeks of having my new bike I forgot my breaks were a thing and crashed my bike, resulting in my now broken wrist. My first broken bone actually.

snippet.textDisplay: I work in a CNC machine shop and I know of this type of incident all to well. I can't say that I understand what the experience was like for you, however, I can speak of my experience with the more extreme outcome. The task I am about to explain was common practice and can be performed safely when done by someone with the right mindset and experience which, however, does not make it right or acceptable practice. Many years ago a co-worker and friend of mine was removing rust from a batch of affected product. They were using emery cloth around a cylindrical steel tube chucked rotating in a large CNC lathe. While they were performing the task the part grabbed a hold of their hand and pulled them into the machine resulting in a severe injury of their hand and arm up to their shoulder. The affected worker had received the worst outcome, however, it also had a significant effect on the employee who made first contact, the team lead in charge, the supervisor who authorized the work, the team lead who cleaned up the mess, and many others in the workers life. From that moment on we banned the operation of a machine with the door open and took a strict stance on it to the effect that if you operate a machine with the door open it would result in immediate termination. It was a difficult road to follow since that was so ingrained in our daily work but something so life changing was enough to drive change. The worker returned to work several years later. They have extremely limited use of their hand and arm causing them to be unable to operate a CNC machine as well as countless other simple tasks. I know that you don't need me to say this but you are very lucky that you only received a flesh wound. One very important thing that I have learned through my years in a machine shop is that you should never compromise on safety under any circumstance even if you are certain that the result may only be a scratch. I chose to leave out some detail to keep this long comment short but I would like to add on more thing. Although I was not present when this took place I could never forget the response from those that were and the conversations I had with them the night of the incident. Thanks for taking the time to read through this.

Many years ago a co-worker and friend of mine was removing rust from a batch of affected product. They were using emery cloth around a cylindrical steel tube chucked rotating in a large CNC lathe. While they were performing the task the part grabbed a hold of their hand and pulled them into the machine resulting in a severe injury of their hand and arm up to their shoulder. The affected worker had received the worst outcome, however, it also had a significant effect on the employee who made first contact, the team lead in charge, the supervisor who authorized the work, the team lead who cleaned up the mess, and many others in the workers life. From that moment on we banned the operation of a machine with the door open and took a strict stance on it to the effect that if you operate a machine with the door open it would result in immediate termination. It was a difficult road to follow since that was so ingrained in our daily work but something so life changing was enough to drive change. The worker returned to work several years later. They have extremely limited use of their hand and arm causing them to be unable to operate a CNC machine as well as countless other simple tasks. I know that you don't need me to say this but you are very lucky that you only received a flesh wound. One very important thing that I have learned through my years in a machine shop is that you should never compromise on safety under any circumstance even if you are certain that the result may only be a scratch. I chose to leave out some detail to keep this long comment short but I would like to add on more thing. Although I was not present when this took place I could never forget the response from those that were and the conversations I had with them the night of the incident. Thanks for taking the time to read through this.

snippet.textDisplay: If you die without a scar on your body... did you ever really live?
snippet.textOriginal: If you die without a scar on your body... did you ever really live?

snippet.textDisplay:
Hey Adam and Tested folks.

Great video. I'm just shared it with my wife, and it's particularly timely because she cut the tip of her finger off yesterday, and is having all the same feelings Adam expressed. She was embarrassed, self critical, and angry with herself.

Anyway, your video reminded her that accidents happen, even when people really know what they were doing, and helped her feel less of all those self incriminating feels. Thank you very much.
snippet.textOriginal:
Hey Adam and Tested folks. 

Great video. I'm just shared it with my wife, and it's particularly timely because she cut the tip of her finger off yesterday, and is having all the same feelings Adam expressed. She was embarrassed, self critical, and angry with herself. 

Anyway, your video reminded her that accidents happen, even when people really know what they were doing, and helped her feel less of all those self incriminating feels. Thank you very much.
